20101220160912.000|20101220160914.000|TR0|
20101220160914.000|20101220160916.000|TR0|Tensions ratcheted up in November when 
20101220160916.000|20101220160919.000|TR0|North Korea fired on a South Korean 
20101220160919.000|20101220160921.000|TR0|island.  The attack killed two Marines and 
20101220160921.000|20101220160924.000|TR0|two civilians. South Korea was conducting 
20101220160924.000|20101220160926.000|TR0|military drills, and the North said dozens 
20101220160926.000|20101220160928.000|TR0|of shells landed inside its territorial 
20101220160928.000|20101220160931.000|TR0|waters.
20101220160931.000|20101220160933.000|TR0|
20101220160933.000|20101220160935.000|TR0|Back further now to the sinking of a South 
20101220160935.000|20101220160938.000|TR0|Korean warship last March.  South Korea 
20101220160938.000|20101220160940.000|TR0|says a North Korean torpedo sank the ship, 
20101220160940.000|20101220160943.000|TR0|killing 46 sailors.  Over the past six 
20101220160943.000|20101220160945.000|TR0|decades, there have been incidents ranging 
20101220160945.000|20101220160947.000|TR0|from small skirmishes to deadly naval 
20101220160947.000|20101220160950.000|TR0|clashes.  The Korean conflict ended with a 
20101220160950.000|20101220160952.000|TR0|truce and not a treaty, so the two 
20101220160952.000|20101220160955.000|TR0|countries are technically still at war.

20101220162259.000|20101220162301.000|TR0|legislative body charged with the solemn

20101220165347.000|20101220165349.000|TR0|SUSAN CANDIOTTI, CNN NATIONAL 
20101220165349.000|20101220165351.000|TR0|CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Maybe that top 
20101220165351.000|20101220165354.000|TR0|that Aunt Mary picked out isn't exactly a 
20101220165354.000|20101220165356.000|TR0|hit. So you bring it back for a refund. 
20101220165356.000|20101220165359.000|TR0|But check out these shoppers. They pick 
20101220165359.000|20101220165401.000|TR0|out some clothes from a rack and go into a 
20101220165401.000|20101220165403.000|TR0|dressing room. When one of them emerges, 
20101220165403.000|20101220165406.000|TR0|she tells the clerk she bought the clothes 
20101220165406.000|20101220165408.000|TR0|earlier and now wants a refund. She gets a 
20101220165408.000|20101220165411.000|TR0|store credit for something she never 
20101220165411.000|20101220165413.000|TR0|bought to begin with. That is return fraud.
20101220165413.000|20101220165415.000|TR0|
20101220165415.000|20101220165418.000|TR0|JOSEPH LAROCCA, NATIONAL RETAIL 
20101220165418.000|20101220165420.000|TR0|FEDERATION: When sales are up, so are 
20101220165420.000|20101220165423.000|TR0|returns. But we're also seeing fraud at 
20101220165423.000|20101220165425.000|TR0|this holiday season and throughout the 
20101220165425.000|20101220165427.000|TR0|year.
20101220165427.000|20101220165430.000|TR0|
20101220165430.000|20101220165432.000|TR0|CANDIOTTI: The National Retail Federation 
20101220165432.000|20101220165434.000|TR0|estimates return fraud losses of $14 
20101220165434.000|20101220165437.000|TR0|billion this year. Four billion alone 
20101220165437.000|20101220165439.000|TR0|during the holidays. It is not only 
20101220165439.000|20101220165442.000|TR0|stealing for store credit, there's also 
20101220165442.000|20101220165444.000|TR0|something called wardrobing.
20101220165444.000|20101220165446.000|TR0|
20101220165446.000|20101220165449.000|TR0|DAN DOYLE, SR. V.P. LOSS PREVENTION, 
20101220165449.000|20101220165451.000|TR0|BEALLS, INC.: That's where somebody would 
20101220165451.000|20101220165454.000|TR0|actually buy a piece of merchandise, use 
20101220165454.000|20101220165456.000|TR0|it and then bring it back to us for full 
20101220165456.000|20101220165458.000|TR0|credit.
20101220165458.000|20101220165501.000|TR0|
20101220165501.000|20101220165503.000|TR0|CANDIOTTI: Not criminal behavior, but to 
20101220165503.000|20101220165506.000|TR0|retailers, it's unethical and costly 
20101220165506.000|20101220165508.000|TR0|because they're stuck with damaged or 
20101220165508.000|20101220165510.000|TR0|soiled goods they can't resell. What is 
20101220165510.000|20101220165513.000|TR0|criminal retailers say is return fraud 
20101220165513.000|20101220165515.000|TR0|that is a form of shoplifting. This woman 
20101220165515.000|20101220165517.000|TR0|selects a brand new rolled up rug in a 
20101220165517.000|20101220165520.000|TR0|department store. She brings it to the

20101220165537.000|20101220165539.000|TR0|return from the cashier.
